grounding: The COVID-19 crisis was a stress test for unemployment insurance schemes as it involved a sudden and unexpected shutdown of a very large set of activities. This forced countries to introduce, often from scratch, income support schemes for workers under new forms of employment and for the self-employed. There was also a considerable expansion of short-time work schemes. As we move past this crisis, labor markets are likely to be characterized by substantial labor reallocation, and major innovations in labor market policy will be required to smooth consumption of workers involved in this reallocation. We survey the large body of research on schemes complementary to unemployment insurance to reduce the costs of reallocation. We focus on short-time work, partial unemployment insurance, and wage insurance and compare their properties to those of standard unemployment benefits. Next we present the main empirical results on the effects of wage insurance, partial unemployment insurance, and short-time work. In the final section we discuss directions for further research.
generated_text: This paper examines the evolution and effectiveness of labor market insurance policies, particularly partial unemployment insurance, wage insurance, and short-time work schemes, in the twenty-first century. These policies are designed to mitigate the economic and social impacts of job loss and underemployment, especially in the context of rapid technological change and economic volatility. Using a combination of empirical analysis and case studies from various developed economies, the research evaluates the extent to which these policies have succeeded in stabilizing household incomes and reducing labor market frictions. The findings suggest that while partial unemployment insurance and short-time work programs have been effective in preserving jobs and smoothing income during economic downturns, wage insurance has shown mixed results, often benefiting higher-skilled workers more than those in low-skilled positions. The paper concludes with recommendations for policy design and implementation to enhance the inclusivity and responsiveness of labor market insurance in the face of ongoing economic challenges.
